Subjects

The neurons of the dorsal root ganglia (DRG), whose axons constitute the peripheral nerves and whose nerve terminals are located at the neuromuscular junctions, mediate pain sensitivity. In Science Immunology, Deshpande et al. identify group 2 innate lymphoid cells (ILC2s) that reside in the peripheral nerves. Sciatic nerve ILC2s express alarmin receptors (ST2, TSLPR and IL-25R) and markers of tissue residence (CD25, ICOS, SCA1 and KIT) and maturation (CD44, KLRG1 and PD1), produce IL-5 and IL-13, but not IL-4, and express genes involved in axogenensis, axon guidance and myelination. Nmur1iCre–eGFPId2fl/fl mice, which are ILC2 deficient, have increased mechanosensitivity and thermosensitivity at steady state or after CFA-induced inflammation in the paw. DRG neurons express IL-4Rα and IL-13Rα1, but not IL-5R, and ILC2-derived IL-13 induces axonal growth in co-cultures. Mice with neuron-specific deletion of IL-4Rα and ILC2-deficient mice, but not Il5−/− mice, have increased occurrence of axon degeneration and show hypersensitivity to mechanical and thermal stimuli and increased axon growth and excitatory glutamatergic signaling in DRG neurons. Thus, ILC2-derived cytokines maintain neuron integrity and regulate pain thresholds.
